data.text:
Need this translated please. And thank you all who are doing this. It has been much help to me. Also, if any of you live in Michigan and know of a place such as a school to learn latin, please let me know. I've been trying to find a class. Thank you.

I can't help much with the translation, but I can help with your question.

There are plenty of free resources available, such as the following:

This forum. Stick around!

Latinum - A free podcast focused on spoken Latin. We know a lot more about how Latin sounded than one would think.

Adler's Grammar - A free, downloadable Latin textbook. This is a must!

Key to Adler's Grammar - The answer key to the exercises in the above book.

NoDictionaries - Once you get the basics down, this makes reading Latin much easier.

Latin Word Study Tool - I have found this tool invaluable in my studies. It won't be much help as you start off, but you'll soon be glad you ever heard of it.

Whitaker's WORDS - I've never used it, but I have heard a lot about it.

Wiktionary - Wiktionary often defines Latin words. A word of caution, though - I've been led astray by Wiktionary on a few occasions, and I only recommend it as a last resort for definitions. For conjugation (the changing of verb endings, you'll get to that before long), it isn't too bad a resource.

Thank you everybody! I will try your suggestions. And I have already tried the Latinum podcast, its nice, but after the first one, it gets a little confusing. So if there are any beginners out there like me, I would suggest a textbook first. lol

I think the meaning may be carried well by the following, even though it is less literal:

Optimas res nondum vidimus.

= We have not yet seen the best (of times).

Or, more literally:

Optimae res nos adhuc exspectant.

= The best things still await us.

The neuter optima could refer to the best concrete things. Res is more general, situational, attitudinal, existential as in the original saying's meaning (as I understand it).
